label: Letter from Abraham Lott to Nathanael Greene
description: Letter from Abraham Lott to Nathanael Greene regarding his poor health, family, and the current state of military affairs, including the enemy retreat from Charlestown, where their current strong holds are, and movements of companies of men.

[Abraham Lott to Nathanael Greene
September 18, 1779
[RvW Box 1 Folder 35; MSS. – A.L.S.]]

Morristown Septr. 18. 1779
Dear General
Your favor of the 25th reached me in this
Town the 27th Ultimo, Just as I was going with Mrs. 
Lott, on a visit to her Brothers at Raritan. After
we had spent Six days in that Neighbourhood [sic] in
visiting our friends I was Seized with a hot nervous
fever, which confined me to my bed for two Days.
The third day finding the fever somewhat abated
I got into my Carriage and after much fatigue
get to Beverwyck. This Journey had the good
effect to produce an intermission, which Dr. [?]
took the advantage of, and by his good manage-
-ment after two fits, has totally Subdued my
disorder. I am still in a state of convalescence,
but have so far recovered as to be able to pay a
visit to Mrs. Lott [and] Mrs. Livingston, now at Colo. [Colonel]
Abeels' where the later expects momently [sic] to
be brought to bed, and upon which Account her
mother attends her. And I hope you will place
my long Accou Silence to the Account of my late
indisposition and not to inattention –
The fare as mentioned by you, that you
can give Mr. [von] Beverhoudt and me, would
be perfectly agreable [sic], and we should most
certainly have been with you if your Quarters
had been more accesable [sic] to Gouty feet [and] Limbs,
but as Mr. Beverhoudt would make but a poor
figure in the rough Grounds you at present
occupy, we have thought it most prudent to 
postpone
[End Page 1]
Postpone our intended visit until you get into a
more hospitable country; tho we both wish to See
the works at Westpoint, which after the labor
expended thereon, we conceive must be very formidable.
It is with great concern that I am informed
by you of the Indisposition of Mrs. Greene [and] the
Two children. If Mr. Beverhoudt [and] family had
not arrived, it would have afforded me a very
peculiar pleasure, if Mrs. Green had spent the
Summer with us, and the more so, as I fondly
flatter myself she would in my family have
escaped the disorder she labors under; but I
can only wish for the present; It may perhaps
be hereafter be in my power to carry those
wishes to effect. I sincerely wish she may
receive benefit from her Journey to the
Eastward, and hope soon to have those wishes
confirmed by you.
The Report you had about Admiral
Arbuthnot's arrivel [sic] has proved true, but from
Every information I have received from the other
side of the Water, they the Reinforcement he
has brought will not create much new trouble
to you – Indeed if the Report we have about
Compt [Comte] D'Estaing's coming on this coast with
a formidable fleet and armament proves
true, I am not without hopes, but we
may Kidnap Sr Harry [Sir Henry Clinton] [and] the admiral in
New York – My wishes in this respect I must
own are extravagant, but hope they are 
not
[End Page 2]
not altogether Chimerical – Certain it is
that their completion is desirable, and more
particularly so to the poor New York Refugees,
among which I cannot help Remembering my-
self – 
The Enemies Retreat from before
Charlestown must in its consequences operate
as a Defeat, and in the Eyes of the neutral
European powers, appear much more
disgraceful – Would it not be a clever thing
if Compte D'Estaing took their whole fleet,
[and] army in Georgia? – Such a thing is not
improbable; nay it is founded in sound reason
that he should make a sweep of that weak
part o the British possessions before he attempts
their more Strong holds in and about New York
The Exploits against Stoney point [and]
Paulus Hook are glorious [and] will not only rank
the Conduction thereof high in the annals of
American faire, but hold them up to all the
powers of Europe, as the bravest of men, who
have executed arduous talks with less bloodshed
than any undertakings of the same nature we
have any accounts of; and it will also convince
Britain that she has no Poltroons to contend
with, but with a people Virtuous [and] who
dare to risque [sic] every thing in defence [sic] of their
much injured rights and priveledges [sic].
The Success of General Sullivan, will
teach the Savages, and their more Savage Allies 
[and]
[End Page 3]
and leaders, that it will be their wisdom to
live upon friendly terms with the United States
of America – They have always been accustomed
to carry fire [and] devastation with them in all their
warfare; they will now experience the effects
thereof, and thence be cautious as they find
they are not out of the reach of the arms of
America, how they the Injure our out Settler,
again – The Penobscott [Penobscot] Expedition I find
has failed to the great damage of the Eastern
Trade, for which I am sincerely sorry; but
perhaps good may come out of Evil – The
Eastern States were so intent upon navigation
and making money that way that they almost
forgot the Army – This Stroke may remind
them of their Duty, and [?] them more
to assist in the General cause- At least I hope
this may be the case.
I am much obliged to you for your
friendly hint about Col.o [Colonel] Livingston [and] so is he
and doubt not he will benefit by your advice
tho' I believe there is much more Smoke than 
fire the few articles he has had out are very
trifling; yet it is imprudent in him to let ever
this Little leak out [and] make a noise
Mrs. Lott Mrs. Livingston [and] Colo. [Colonel] Abeel's
family I am in respectfull Salutations
to you [and] all friends with and about you
wish Dear General
your faithful hbl. Servts [humble Servants]
Maj.r Genl. [Major General] Greene Abrm [Abraham] Lott
[Endorsed on left margin:]  From Abr. [Abraham] Lott 18 Sepr.
1779
[End Page 4]
